newsitem.title: UK: UK Conservative right-winger urges truce on Europe.
newsitem.headline: UK Conservative right-winger urges truce on Europe.

text.p: The chairman of a right-wing Conservative group which has pressed the government to rule out joining a single European currency on Thursday called on supporters to accept the compromise position of Prime Minister John Major.

Speaking to a fringe meeting at the party's annual conference in Bournemouth, Lord Cecil Parkinson said: "I don't think any Conservative at this stage need keep up pressure on the cabinet to go further than they have."
Parkinson, a former cabinet minister, is chairman of the "Conservative Way Forward.'
In its quarterly magazine published just before the conference, the group said in an editorial: "The current 'wait- and-see' compromise...will be quite impossible to sustain in a general election."

Parkinson was speaking shortly after Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke, a leading supporter of a single currency, had won a standing ovation from the conference for a speech in which he backed Major's policy of not deciding on membership until after the next election.
"Above all we must present a united front to the electorate and stop this argument about Europe," he said.
"If we carry on dividing ourselves on this issue, the beneficiaries would be a party which will take us far further into Europe," he added in a reference to the opposition Labour Party.
Parkinson said opponents of a single currency within the party could take comfort from the fact that Major has promised a referendum if his government did propose to jettison sterling.
"We can win that argument, and if we can't win it, we deserve to lose it," he said.
